name: 3-cyano-1-nitrobenzene
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of a cyano group increases molecular polarity and intermolecular forces, leading to an estimated increase of about +70°C in melting point. A nitro group also substantially raises the melting point due to its electronegativity and ability to participate in strong dipole-dipole interactions, possibly contributing an additional +40°C. There is no specific synergistic effect quantified between the cyano and nitro groups that would justify deviation from a simple additive effect; hence, these groups are treated independently in their contributions to the melting point.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C.
- Nitro group: Nitro groups are strong electron-withdrawing groups that can significantly increase the melting point due to their ability to participate in intermolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions. This effect might be around +80 degrees Celsius.
- Cyano group: Cyano groups are also electron-withdrawing and can increase the melting point due to their linear geometry and the ability to engage in dipole-dipole interactions. This effect might be around +50 degrees Celsius.
Adding these increments together gives us a predicted melting point: 5.5 (benzene) + 80 (nitro group) + 50 (cyano group) = 135.5 degrees Celsius.
##Prediction: 135.5
